questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing  5×13×7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian tumor in a young woman which consists of primordial germ cells and is histologically similar to seminoma suggests a diagnosis of an ovarian dysgerminoma. It does not secrete sex hormones.

Dysgerminoma usually arises in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumour diagnosed during pregnancy. They are primitive neoplasms that do not have the potential for further differentiation. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

The tumor is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and β-hCG. Serum LDH and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. 

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Associated feature

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration

Mature teratoma - Rokitansky protruberance

Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal

Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell

Remember:

Dysgerminoma

(Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP
  • L: LDH

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The cause of lactational amenorrhea is increased prolactin secretion as a result of the baby sucking at the mother's breast.

Lactational amenorrhea:

  • Type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect of prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided she remains amenorrhoeic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur, despite amenorrhoea and might need other forms of contraception.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Asherman's syndrome?

choices.text: Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

questions.solution:
Asherman's syndrome has Normal FSH, Normal LH, and Normal estradiol.

Asherman's syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium, most commonly as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages. Oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae. The laboratory investigations and hormonal assays are generally normal in isolated cases of uterine synechiae. Diagnosis is generally established using hysteroscopy. Moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. 

Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

Premature Ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (>40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. The other findings consistent with POF include low estradiol and an elevated FSH/LH ratio.

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrone(E1) levels are elevated but estradiol level in PCOS is low in comparison to Estrone (E1). 

Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. Affected women may present with panhypopituitarism and may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to the deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to the deficiency of gonadotropins).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Other options:

Option A: Hysteroscopy and Endometrial Biopsy: These evaluate conditions within the uterine cavity, such as polyps or hyperplasia, but endometriosis involves ectopic endometrial tissue outside the uterus, making this investigation unhelpful for its diagnosis.  

Option B: Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVUS): While TVUS can detect ovarian endometriomas, it cannot reliably identify peritoneal or deep infiltrating endometriosis, limiting its utility in providing a comprehensive diagnosis.  

Option C: Hysterosalpingography (HSG): This test is primarily used to assess tubal patency and uterine contour in infertility workups but does not provide direct visualization of endometrial implants, making it unsuitable for diagnosing endometriosis.  

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: At what point do you begin plotting on a partogram when the first contractions occur?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.

A partograph was designed by WHO for use in developing countries. Partograph is similar for nulliparas and multiparas.

Active phase starts at 3cm cervical dilatation and progress should be no slower than 1cm/hour.

A 4 hour wait is recommended before intervention when the active phase is slow.

In the modified partograph, there is no plotting of the latent phase. The partograph is plotted once active labor begins.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan syndrome also called post-partum pituitary necrosis refers to the necrosis of the pituitary gland following significant post-partum bleeding, hypovolemia, and shock. It may present acutely as an endocrine emergency or present chronically.The late presentation has the following features:

  • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

Option B: Hyperthyroidism can cause oligomenorrhoea and amenorrhea but is likely to have symptoms of hyperthyroidism like weight loss, palpitations, tremors, heat intolerance, dyspnea on exertion, diarrhoea and muscle weakness.

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Pituitary apoplexy is a condition in which there is a haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. This disorder commonly occurs in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. This patient does not have any signs of adenoma and a history of PPH makes Sheehan syndrome more likely.

questions.text: A 33-week pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia presents with clinical features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. What is the best management approach?

choices.text: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks
Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks

questions.solution:
The definitive management of PIH/eclampsia is termination of pregnancy only.

Indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, in cases of pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Fetal compromise

Other options:

Option B: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks: This would be the answer if it were mild pre-eclampsia. Here, it is a case of severe pre-eclampsia with HELLP syndrome.

Option C: Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks: MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia in patients with severe pre-eclampsia and pregnancy is terminated at >34 weeks. If 27-34 weeks, give corticosteroids and deliver after 24 hours of the last dose of steroid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in?
questions.solution:
Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths (as shown in the image below). Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition.

Genital warts:

Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. They are most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

 

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as a crop of small domed vesicles with central umbilication. It is caused by the pox virus and it spreads by close sexual or nonsexual contact and by autoinoculation.

Option C: Chancroid appears as small papules that develop into painful ulcerating pustules. They are associated with unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is caused by H. ducreyi.

Option D: Herpes appears as multiple crops of vesicles and ulcers.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of how many births are referred to as a grand multipara?
questions.solution:
A pregnant woman with a history of >4 births is referred to as a grand multipara.

Terminologies used in pregnancy:

Gravida indicates the number of times a female has been pregnant. It includes present as well as past pregnancy, irrespective of the period of gestation.

Para indicates the number of previous pregnancies that had progressed beyond the period of viability (28 weeks of gestation or more).

  1. A nullipara is one who has never completed a pregnancy to the stage of viability. She may or may not have aborted previously.
  2. A nulligravida is one who is not now and never has been pregnant.
  3. A primipara is one who has delivered one viable child. Parity is not increased even if the fetuses are many (twins, triplets).
  4. A primigravida is one who is pregnant for the first time.
  5. A multigravida is one who has previously been pregnant. She may have aborted or have delivered a viable baby.
  6. A multipara is one who has completed two or more pregnancies to the stage of viability or more. A pregnant woman with a previous history of more than four births is called a grand multipara.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida with twin gestation presents to the clinic in active labor. The first baby is in breech presentation and the second baby is in cephalic presentation. What is the best step of management in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the first twin is in breech (non-cephalic presentation), the best step of management is to deliver through cesarean section.

Scheme of management of twins in labor:

  1. If the first twin/ both twins are in the non-cephalic presentation: deliver through cesarean section.
  2. If the first twin is in vertex presentation: Deliver the first twin through vaginal delivery and do not give methergine post-delivery of the first baby. Delivering the second twin, If it is in,
  • Breech: Deliver through breech extraction
  • Transverse lie
    • If the obstetrician is skilled in podalic version: Internal podalic version and breech extraction under GA. 
    • If the obstetrician is unskilled: External version into a longitudinal lie preferably cephalic or if that fails podalic. 
  • Vertex: Vaginal delivery, assisted forceps/ventouse.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech
  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Metzenbaum scissors. It is used to cut dissect and cut tissues such as the peritoneum and adhesions. It is similar to Mayo scissors in that the ends are the same on both scissor halves, but its handles are longer and its middle section is slightly narrower.

The given image shows the Metzenbaum scissors:

 

Other options:

Option A- Umbilical cord scissors are used to cut the umbilical cord soon after delivery.

 

Option C- Episiotomy scissor is bent on the edge. It has a blunt tup that goes inside the vagina. It is used to perform episiotomy during delivery. 

 

Option D- Embryo scissors are used to perform destructive procedures of the dead fetus, including depacitation, and cleidotomy. These procedures are rarely done nowadays.  

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.
  • Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology Mostly obstetric causes mostly gynecological surgeries
Clinical Continuous dribbling of urine—no micturition Continuous dribbling of urine but can also micturate
Methylene swab test Swab stains with methylene blue   Swab stains with urine—but not with methylene blue
IVP Normal Hydronephrosis presents on the affected side

The methylene blue 3 swab test:

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle and one just above the introitus.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

questions.text: A P5 female bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate IV fluids with oxytocin.  However, the patient continues to bleed over the next 10 min even after adequate uterine massage. On examination,  she is tachycardic, hypotensive and the uterus is soft and boggy.  What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management is to carry out balloon tamponade.

  • When the uterine bleeding is unresponsive to uterotonic agents, bimanual uterine compression can be performed, IV lines must be placed and volume resuscitation started.
  • A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity. 

Other options mentioned are surgical methods of management. These are tried after all forms of medical management have failed.

questions.text: The dose of Anti D for alloimmunization in a treated case of ectopic pregnancy is ______
questions.solution:
300 microgram is the dose Anti-D which is used for alloimmunization after surgical correction of ectopic pregnancy.

The dose of Anti-D in 1st-trimester abortion and in a surgically treated case of ectopic is 300 micrograms. In 2nd trimester abortion, and in Rh-negative mothers (where it is given within 72 hours of pregnancy termination), the dose is 300 micrograms.

 Anti-D is not given when the ectopic is corrected through medical techniques.

Note: 50 micrograms is the minimum dose of Anti-D which can be used for alloimmunization, but 300 micrograms is the recommended dose as per the recent NICE guidelines.

questions.text: All of the following findings indicate uterine scar rupture, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of station of presenting part

questions.solution:
Maternal bradycardia is not a feature of uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is one in which all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa ) are disrupted any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labor, manual removal of placenta, dilatation, and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features of scar dehiscence:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - Formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy-For a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility. A cornual fibroid (blocking the tube) and submucous fibroid (habitual abortions).
  • Chances of torsion. 
  • Urinary tract infection. A fibroid pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy and requiring surgery.
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. 
Results show: sperm concentration: 10 million/ml; pH: 7.5; volume: 2 mL. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
This male, with a sperm concentration of 10 million/mL, has findings suggestive of oligospermia.

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL. Concentrations of 16 million/mL is Normospermia (Option A)

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of sperm analysis.

Other options :

The total sperm motility is less than 40% and the progressive sperm motility is less than 32% in asthenospermia (Option D)

Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen (Option C)

Semen analysis  Normal reference value with reference to lower limit 
Volumae 1.5 mL 
pH 7.2–7.8
Viscosity <3 (Scale 0–4)
Sperm concentration 15 million/mL
Total sperm count >39 million/ejaculate
Motility >Progressive motility = 32%
Morphology >4% Normal form
Viability 58% or more living 
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/mL
Round cells  <5 million/mL
Sperm agglutination <10% spermatozoa with adherent particles

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

  • Volume: 1.5 mL
  • PH: 7.2–7.8
  • Viscosity : <3 (scale 0–4)
  • Sperm concentration ≥15 million/mL 
  • Total sperm count: ≥39 million/per ejaculate 
  • Motility: 40% or more with 32% progressive motility
  • Forward progression: >2 (Scale of 0-4)
  • Normal forms: 4% (strict criteria) 
  • Vitality: 58% or more 
  • White blood cells: < 1 million/mL
  • Round cells: 5 million/mL
  • Sperm agglutination: <2 (Scale 0-3)

questions.text:
Match the following patients with Uterine prolapse with their best treatment option.
          Age/condition       Management
  1. Nulliparous women with desire for future pregnancy
  2. 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy
  3. 30-year-old in puerperial period
  4. 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.
  1. Fothergill's operation
  2. Cervicopexy
  3. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
  4.  Ring pessary
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: The image given below depicts which abnormality of the placenta?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts placenta succenturiata in which one or more small lobes of placenta may be placed at a distance from main placental margin.

Its complications are

  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Uterine sepsis
  • Polyp formation

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Velamentous cord insertion - The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

questions.text: Singer's alkali denaturation test is performed for
questions.solution:
Singer's alkali denaturation test is performed for Vasa previa.

Detection of nucleated RBCs using apt test or Singer's alkali denaturation test is diagnostic of vasa previa. It is based on the fact that fetal hemoglobin is resistant to alkali denaturation. 

Both Apt Test and Kleihauer-Betke Test can be used to detect the presence of fetal blood within a sample.

 

Apt Test

Kleihauer Betke Test

Reagent

NaOH

Citric acid phosphate buffer

Assessment

Qualitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A 24-year-old Rh-negative G2P1 mother was delivered by cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation. The baby is found to be Rh-positive. To access fetomaternal transfusion a Kleihaeur Betke test was done which detected 20 ml of fetal RBCs. What is the dose of anti-D that should be administered to the mother? (Assume fetal hematocrit to be 50 percent)
questions.solution:
10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.Hence for 20 mL of fetal RBCs, 400 µg of anti-D should be administered.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

Principle: Fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: The most common type of conjoined twins among the given options is _______
questions.solution:
The most common type of conjoined twins among the given options is thoracophagus.

Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types:

  • Ventral
    • Rostral
      • Omphalopagus (abdomen)
      • Thoracopagus (upper chest)
      • Cephalopagus (head)
    • Caudal
      • Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angles)
    • Lateral
      • Paraphagus (side-by-side fusion with a shared pelvis)
  • Dorsal
    • Craniopagus (skull)
    • Rachipagus (vertebral arches)
    • Pyopagus (pelvis)

Note: The most common type of conjoined twins is parapagus. Since the parapagus is not mentioned in the options, the thoracopagus is the most common among the given options.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination with 2 fingers in the anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: Bimanual examination with 2 fingers in anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus, abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus which is due to softening of the isthmus. 

It is seen during pregnancy at 6-10 wks.

This sign is based on the fact that the upper part of the body of the uterus is enlarged by the growing fetus, the lower part of the body is empty and extremely soft and the cervix is comparatively firm.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Suction and Evacuation (S&E) is best carried out between 7-12 weeks.

The various methods of termination of pregnancy are: 

Timing Medical methods Surgical methods

1st trimester

(up to 12 weeks)
  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Methotrexate and misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and misoprostol
 		  
  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation -
  • Rapid method
  • Slow method 

2nd trimester

(13 - 20 weeks)
  • Misoprostol
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Dinoprostone
  • Carboprost
  • Dilatation and evacuation
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions
  • Oxytocin infusion
  • Hysterotomy

questions.text: A 26 year old woman, G2P1, is informed after her first trimester scan , that the fetus has open spina bifida. At 30 weeks of gestation, her USG scan would most likely report:
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical vignette, at 30 weeks of gestation, her USG scan would most likely report a single deepest vertical pocket of 9 cm in a fetus with open spina bifida.

Spina bifida is one of the causes of polyhydramnios which is diagnosed when the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm. 

Open spina bifida causes increased transudation from the meninges , leading to increasing amounts of liquor amnii production i.e. polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8 cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options :

Option A : AFI=4 cm implies oligohydramnios (AFI< 5 cm or DVP< 2cm).

Option B: DVP=2 cm implies oligohydramnios.

Option C : AFI = 10 cm implies normal AFI (5-25 cm).

 

Related Pearl: Causes of oligo and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

Diabetes, cardiac & renal diseases, liver failure

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion Nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.

According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU).
