questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergic, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text:
Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include:
  1. No active vaginal bleeding 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  3. Reactive NST
  4. Maternal Hb ≥10 g%
  5. Hematocrit value of at least 30%
questions.solution:
1,2,3,4 and 5 are suitable case for expectant management of placenta previa.

Risk factors for placenta previa

  • Multigravida
  • Age > 35 years
  • Smoking
  • Previous cesarean section or myomectomy
  • Abnormal placental size and lobes
  • Prior curettage

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’. 
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Degree of placenta previa:

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for C-section.

The image below shows the types of placenta previa.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk
    • Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women
  • Use of tocolytics if there are uterine contractions.

The pregnancy is carried till 37 weeks as part of expectant management. During this time, if there is fetal distress or a bleeding episode, then terminate immediately.

Note - Cervical cerclage is not a part of expectant management

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina which started a week earlier. On examination, the vaginal walls are congested with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Whiff's test is positive and the gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching, foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and a positive Whiff test with clue cells in the gram staining suggest bacterial vaginosis. It is treated with metronidazole.

Bacterial vaginosis:

It is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells has a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

The below image shows the presence of clue cells.

Other options:

Option B: Nystatin pessary is used in the treatment of candidal vaginitis. They present with severe itching, dysuria, and passage of thick curdy discharge. On examination, the vagina is congested and thick curdy discharge can be seen at the vulval mucocutaneous junction and posterior fornix.

Options C and D: Tetracycline and azithromycin are used in the treatment of chlamydial infection. They usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and sometimes cervicitis. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score?
questions.solution:
The woman has had two pregnancies in total - the previous twin pregnancy and the current pregnancy, with the first pregnancy resulting in delivery at term. Hence, her obstetric score would be G2P1 (Gravida - 2, Para - 1). 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
  • L - Living children.

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins for the first time is expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. 

Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: What is the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.

During early puerperium, sloughing of the decidual tissue causes vaginal discharge which is known as lochia. Most women experience an increase in the amount of bleeding at 7-14 days secondary to the sloughing of the eschar on the placental site. But the average duration of lochial discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days.

The lochial discharge appears as follows:

Name Colour Timing after delivery Content
Lochia rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink After 3-4 days

WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms
Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat cells

The persistence of red lochia beyond one week might be an indicator of uterine subinvolution. The presence of an offensive odour, large pieces of tissue or blood clots in lochia, excessive or absence of lochia might be a sign of infection.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis. This condition can be diagnosed using MR venography.

Cortical vein thrombosis :    

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation is highly variable. Headache is the most common symptom. Motor or sensory deficits may be seen. Seizures along with focal deficits in the absence of raised intracranial pressure are suggestive of cortical venous thrombosis. Brain MRI with MR venography is a sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made and she was posted for laparoscopy surgery. During the procedure,  dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis and the next step in the management of this patient is cystectomy and adhesiolysis. 

After the surgery the patient is advised to start infertility treatment too.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • Gestrinone is an anti-estrogenic, anti-progestational, and mildly anabolic drug that reduces sex-hormone-binding globulin to release free testosterone. It also decreases the LH surge. It causes regression of lesions and amenorrhea. It is a 19-nortestosterone derivative similar to danazol, but with fewer side effects. 
  • Combined oral contraceptives are used for symptom control and alleviate disease. These also cause menstrual cycle regulation and delay pregnancy. 
  • Oral progestogens exert an anti-estrogenic effect and cause decidualization and endometrial atrophy. This causes disease regression. It doesn't prevent ovulation, thus is suitable for women who are trying to conceive. 
  • Mirena IUCDs reduce dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. It is a single-sitting treatment with minimal side effects. 
  • Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are anti-estrogens given for disease regression. 
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs like mefenamic acid and naproxen relieve dysmenorrhea.

Therapeutic procedures:

  • Aspiration of Peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac removes PGE2, relieves dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and improves fertility 
  • Destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser or CO2 vaporization can be attempted. 
  • Larger lesions and chocolate cysts can be excised. 
  • Cystectomy can be done for pelvic pain but can reduce fertility potential. 
  • Laparoscopic breaking of adhesions relieves dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. It also restores tubal patency and improves ovulation. Pre-sacral neurectomy can be done simultaneously.. 
  • Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is ligated first during surgical management of postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Anastomosis of uterine and ovarian arteries

questions.solution:
The uterine artery is the first artery that is ligated during the surgical management of postpartum hemorrhage(PPH).

If PPH is due to a flabby uterus on examination; then uterine massage is done to improve atony. Methergine 0.2 mg and oxytocin are administered to promote the contraction of the atonic uterus. Also, the uterus has to be explored for any retained membranes or cotyledons of the placenta.

Initial resuscitative measures include the infusion of 2L of normal saline (crystalloids) through large-bore IV cannulas. Relevant blood investigations such as blood count, grouping, cross-matching, LFT, RFT, and coagulation studies are done. 20 units of oxytocin in 1L of normal saline at the rate of 60 drops/minute is started along with blood transfusion. The bladder is catheterized.

Medical management of PPH includes carbetocin, a long-acting oxytocin analog, which is also effective. PGF-2 alpha, misoprostol(1000 micrograms), tranexamic acid, and calcium gluconate IV 1g slowly are given in refractory cases.


Uterine packing with balloon tamponade, foley catheter, and Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used as a first-line surgical intervention for atonic PPH.
Surgical methods for the management of atonic PPH in sequence are discussed below: 

  1. B -Lynch compression sutures act as a tamponade to control hemorrhage.
  2. The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated next.
  3. Uterine and ovarian arteries anastomosis are ligated if the bleeding persists.
  4. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and angiographic embolization is done if the above-mentioned methods failed.
  5. Following this, a hysterectomy is the last resort.

Related Pearl: Contraindications to Uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • A desire for future pregnancy: Poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions following UAE would negatively impact fertility, and result in obstetric complications or adverse fetal effects.
  • Postmenopausal status: The procedure is indicated primarily for premenopausal women since fibroids tend to decrease in size and symptoms improve or resolve after menopause. An enlarging uterus after menopause should raise the suspicion of malignancy and careful follow-up is warranted.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: They are pedunculated and may detach either intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. Detachment may be associated with sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: The volume of necrosis after UAE in a large fibroid uterus can be substantial with a proportionate level of postprocedural pain and risk of infection.
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

choices.text: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products of conception can also be seen.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is a functional or anatomical impairment in the retentive power of the cervix (or internal os). It is characterized by repeated, mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. It leads to the escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception.

Cerclage is the procedure done to strengthen the cervix in patients with cervical incompetence. Contraindications of cervical cerclage include:

  • Ruptured membranes
  • Intrauterine infection
  • Uterine contractions
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Cervical dilatation >4 cm
  • Fetal death or defect

Cervical incompetence is associated with various risk factors such as prior preterm birth, congenital uterine anomalies, iatrogenic (dilatation and curettage, induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation, vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix, amputation of the cervix, etc), and multiple gestations.

In the interconceptional period, diagnosis is made with the passage of number 6-8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain. Investigations for cervical incompetence during pregnancy include:

  • Per speculum examination - shows cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - funneling of internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12-14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.
 
Shirodkar and McDonald's methods of cervical cerclage are the commonly performed cerclage procedures during pregnancy. In McDonald's method, a non-absorbable (mersilene) suture material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os, whereas in the Shirodkar method, non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is used. Removal of stitch should be done at the 37th week of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labor or if signs of abortion are seen. Laparoscopic abdominal cerclage is used for non-pregnant patients.

questions.text: Identify the given image based on the Doppler findings.
questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts the reversal of end-diastolic flow (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. 

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)

Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise - terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks.

Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death - terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age.

questions.text: A teenager presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distribution of hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typically begins in late adolescence or the early 20s.

Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset of hirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours.

Other less common causes of hirsutism include:

  • Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Tumours of the ovary and adrenal gland
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Drug-induced

Virilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. It has the following features:

  • Acne
  • Increased oily skin
  • Temporal balding
  • Clitoromegaly
  • Deepening of the voice
  • Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus
  • Atrophy of breasts

Hypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the lab criteria for diagnosis of APLA syndrome?
questions.solution:
Raised aPTT is not a lab criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before 10 weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), also referred to as a recurrent miscarriage or habitual abortion, is historically defined as 3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks from the last menstrual period. 

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. In view of the prolonged second stage of labor, a mediolateral episiotomy was given to aid instrumental delivery.  It is usually angled at ______
questions.solution:
The mediolateral episiotomy is angled at 60°.

Episiotomy is a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour. It is done to 

  • To enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus.
  • To minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia
  • To reduce the stress and strain on the fetal head.

It is given during crowning when the head is visible. There are many types like median, mediolateral, lateral and j shaped. Among these, mediolateral episiotomy is preferred.

The mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for stretch distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and distortion resolution, it ultimately yields an incision 45-degrees from the midline.

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with a USG report suggesting fetus in breech position and on per vaginal examination, toes of the foot can be felt. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests that the fetus is in a footling breech position, which is an indication for a cesarean section.

In footling breech, one or both legs are extended at the hip, so that the foot is the presenting part.

A major complication of breech presentation is cord prolapse. In the cord prolapse, the umbilical cord drops down below the presenting part of the baby and becomes compressed.

Factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

Other options:

Option A: Intrernal podalic version is a maneuver used only in the delivery of a second twin. (Option A)

Option C: External cephalic version is a maneuver used before labor in a woman who has reached 36 weeks’ gestation with a breech fetus. (Option C)

Option D: Assisted breech delivery is performed when there are no factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus. (Option D)

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Footling Knee presentation Complete/flexed
Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Both thighs and legs are partially extended Thighs extended, Knee flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed.
Presenting part: Buttocks and genitalia Foot Knee Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 was admitted to the labor room at 34 weeks of gestation in view of  BP - 150/90mmHg and Urine albumin - 2+. Which of the following drugs is not used to control BP in this patient ______
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of pre-eclampsia. Methyl dopa, labetalol, and hydralazine are agents used for the management of pre-eclampsia.

ACE Inhibitor effects on the fetus: These drugs inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. They can cause severe fetal malformations when given in the second and third trimesters.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers 
  • Diuretics (Contraindicated as an anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)
  • Reserpine
  • Sodium Nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)
  • Diazoxide

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placental tissue invading the myometrium of the uterus suggestive of placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents at 33 weeks gestation with intermittent uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 80% effaced and 2.5cm dilated. To allow fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). 

  • Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. 
  • Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies, and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labor to look for cervical incompetence. 

It is diagnosed by:

  • Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 min with/without pain. 
  • Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% 
  • TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding PV

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Management includes short-term therapy with tocolytics, given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labor for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary center (centers with NICU). The tocolytics include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

questions.text: The double decidual sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
The double decidual sign is seen in intrauterine pregnancy.

The double decidual sac sign is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy. It is seen as two concentric rings consisting of outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

The pseudo gestational sac is a collection of fluid between the endometrial layers, surrounded by a thick decidua. Its presence increases the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.

Differences between pseudo gestational sac and true gestational sac:

Feature Pseudo gestational sac True intrauterine gestational sac
Location within the endometrial cavity Central Eccentric
Shape  Usually ovoid Usually round
Fetal and yolk sac poles Absent Present
Double ring sign Absent Seen
Intradecidual sign Absent Seen

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following skin finding in a pregnant woman needs further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Image 2 showing acanthosis nigricans is not a normal change seen in pregnancy and hence it needs evaluation if seen in pregnancy. The other images show striae gravidarum, chloasma gravidarum and linea alba which are normal changes seen in pregnancy.

Acanthosis nigricans(AN) is characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. More common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance is the most common association with AN, and it can regress with weight loss. It is more common in patients with darker skin. 

Other conditions associated with AN:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • HAIR-AN syndrome
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gynaecological cancer

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with topical retinoids or topical keratolytics

Other options:

Option A: Linea nigra is a brownish-black pigmented area that stretches from the xiphisternum to the symphysis pubis in the midline. The pigmentary changes may be due to melanocyte-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary. The pigmentation disappears after delivery. Similar changes are observed in women taking oral contraceptives may be due to estrogen and progesterone may be related to it as.

Option C: Striae gravidarum is slightly depressed linear marks with varying length and breadth found in pregnancy. They are predominantly found in the abdominal wall below the umbilicus. They appear pinkish in colour. They can sometimes be found over the thighs and breasts. These stretch marks represent the scar tissues in the deeper layer of the cutis. 

Option D: Chloasma gravidarum also called pregnancy mask is an extreme form of pigmentation around the cheek, forehead, and around eyes. It may be patchy or diffuse. It disappears spontaneously after delivery.

questions.text: Serum beta hCG testing is required to diagnose which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects

questions.solution:
Repeated serum beta hCG testing is done for a molar pregnancy.

Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum β hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the β hCG levels.

The initial β-hCG level is obtained 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. 

It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained. This normally happens in 4-8 weeks. 

After this, β hCG levels are measured monthly for 6 months. Women who undergo chemotherapy must be followed up for 1 year.

Other options:

Options A and B: Downs syndrome and Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects require Maternal serum AFP testing but not serum Beta hCG testing.

Option D: Rh-negative pregnancy requires Coombs antibody testing.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who presented with secondary dysmenorrhea has been diagnosed with endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogue (Option D).
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D:Danazol (OptionC)
  • G:Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone (Option B).

Surgical management:

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA).
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.
